policy_statement.purpose: To establish standards for identifying and remediating source code vulnerabilities through static analysis.
policy_statement.description: This policy defines requirements for SAST implementation, vulnerability management, and secure code development practices.
policy_statement.applicability: All development teams and applications with custom source code.
policy_statement.enforcement: Mandatory SAST scans in CI/CD pipeline with quality gates.
policy_statement.exceptions: Legacy applications may request temporary exemptions through the Security Review Board.

executive_summary: The current code base contains a critical hard‑coded credential and a high‑severity SQL injection risk, indicating an immediate need for stronger secure‑coding controls. By embedding automated SAST into the CI/CD pipeline and enforcing remediation timelines, the organization will reduce exploitation likelihood and protect sensitive data.
scope: Application source code security analysis for all internally developed and third‑party integrated software components.
objectives: Integrate automated SAST tools into every build pipeline and enforce pass/fail gates.
Ensure timely remediation of identified vulnerabilities based on risk ranking.
Establish continuous monitoring and reporting to maintain compliance with NIST CSF and ISO 27001.

risk_assessment.business_impact: Exploitation of hard‑coded credentials could lead to full system compromise, while SQL injection may expose customer data, resulting in regulatory fines, loss of reputation, and operational disruption.

security_controls.title: Input Validation Framework
security_controls.description: Implement a centralized input validation library that enforces allow‑list validation for all external data.
implementation_steps: Select a vetted validation library (e.g., OWASP ESAPI).
Integrate the library into all entry‑point modules.
Enforce use of prepared statements for database access.
Add unit tests that verify validation logic for each API.

security_controls.title: Secret Management
security_controls.description: Remove hard‑coded secrets from source code and store them in a centralized secret vault.
implementation_steps: Identify all hard‑coded credentials using automated search patterns.
Migrate secrets to a vault solution (e.g., HashiCorp Vault, Azure Key Vault).
Update application code to retrieve secrets at runtime via secure APIs.
Restrict vault access using role‑based access control and audit logging.

security_controls.title: Continuous SAST Monitoring
security_controls.description: Run static analysis on every code commit and generate actionable findings.
implementation_steps: Configure SAST tool (e.g., SonarQube, Checkmarx) to scan on pull‑request creation.
Define quality gates: block merge on any Critical or High findings.
Export scan results to the ticketing system for tracking.
Review and tune rule sets quarterly to reduce false positives.

remediation_actions.title: Eliminate hard‑coded credentials in config/settings.py
remediation_actions.success_criteria: No hard‑coded secrets remain; application retrieves credentials from approved secret vault.

remediation_actions.title: Fix SQL Injection vulnerability in src/controllers/LoginController.java
remediation_actions.success_criteria: All database interactions use parameterized queries or ORM methods; static scan shows no SQL injection findings.

remediation_actions.title: Remove unused import statements in src/utils/helpers.py
remediation_actions.success_criteria: Code base contains no unused imports; linting tool reports zero warnings.

monitoring_requirements: Automated SAST scans triggered on every commit and nightly full scans.
Weekly dashboard review of open SAST findings by the Application Security Lead.
Quarterly security code review sessions with peer developers.
Integration of scan results with the SIEM for trend analysis.
review_schedule: Quarterly policy review and annual audit
